qas.question: If a team is relegated in the Premier League what type of tv payment do they receive?

answers.text: The Premier League distributes a portion of its television revenue to clubs that are relegated from the league in the form of "parachute payments".

qas.question: What do critics have to say about this payment?

answers.text: critics maintain that the payments actually widen the gap between teams that have reached the Premier League and those that have not,

qas.question: What has happened to some of the clubs who weren't able to get back into the Premier League right away?
How much does a Football League club receive on average for their television revenues?

answers.text: the average Football League Championship club receives £2 million

qas.question: How does this compare an average Premier League team?

answers.text: the average Premier League team receives £55 million

qas.question: To which type of team are parachute payments distributed to in the Premier League?
Starting in the 2013-14 season, parachute payments are in excess of what amount of revenue?
What is said to widen between clubs who reach the Premier League and those who do not thanks to parachute payments?

plausible_answers.text: distributes a portion of its television revenue to clubs that are relegated from the league in the form of "parachute payments

qas.question: What does the Football League Championship club do with a portion of TV revenue?

plausible_answers.text: widen the gap between teams that have reached the Premier League and those that have not

qas.question: What do supporters say about the parachute payments?

plausible_answers.text: clubs that are relegated from the league

qas.question: To what type of team does the Football League Championship club distribute parachute payments?
How much to the "bouncing back" payments exceed?

context: <a0_0>The Premier League <b8_0>distributes a portion of its television revenue to <b10_0>clubs that are <a5_0>relegated<a5_0/> from the league<b10_0/> in the form of "parachute payments<b8_0/>".<a0_0/> Starting with the 2013–14 season, these payments are in excess of <a6_0><b11_0>£60 million<a6_0/> over four seasons.<b11_0/> Though designed to help teams adjust to the loss of television revenues (<a4_0>the average Premier League team receives £55 million<a4_0/> while <a3_0>the average Football League Championship club receives £2 million<a3_0/>), <a1_0>critics maintain that the payments actually <b9_0>widen <a7_0>the gap<a7_0/> between teams that have reached the Premier League and those that have not<b9_0/>,<a1_0/> leading to the common occurrence of teams "bouncing back" soon after their relegation. For some clubs who have failed to win immediate promotion back to the Premier League, <a2_0>financial problems<a2_0/>, including in some cases administration or even liquidation have followed. Further relegations down the footballing ladder have ensued for several clubs unable to cope with the gap.
